utterance:
What a queer old witch-like house! How strange that
it should be here on this street! Who does live there?
speaker: somebody

utterance:
O, that's the old Avery place. It can't
be sold till old Miss Zarviah Avery dies; she has the life-
right, and she won't live anywhere else.
speaker: narrator

utterance:
Now, you wretches, if you don't get out this minute,
I'll-
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance: We want our dog. He's run into your old house!
speaker: the boldest

utterance:
You sha'n't have your dog! and if you don't clear out,
I'll call the watch!
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance: Who cares for you, old Witch Avery?
speaker: boys

utterance: We'll come in for all you!
speaker: boys

utterance: Catch us if you can! Where's your policeman?
speaker: boys

utterance: Come here, doggie!
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance: good doggie!
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance: Well, did I ever!
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance: you poor cre'tur!
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance: Well, I will,
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance:
poor doggie! I won't let any
one catch you again; but you must be washed clean.
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance:
The cre'tur really seems to know that there are victuals
getting ready,
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance: no doubt he's hungry;
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance: Lie down, doggie,
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance:
you shall have your supper
by-and-by.
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance: Well, did I ever!
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance:
No, I never did;
why, the cre'tur all but talks! Well, well,
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance:
you
shall have your supper right away,
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance: What, more?
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance: WELL, of all things! Who would have thought it?
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance: Poor Eben!
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance:
I reely was hard on him. I wish
now I had been more patient with Trip-just for his sake.
Well, well, we do things that we can't take back, if we want to
ever so much,
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance: Did the wicked boys plague you?
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance:
Well, they sha'n't any more; I'll take care
of you.
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance:
Oh! oh! Why, Trip-pee! Why! why! Good dog!
Don't! don't!
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance:
There,
there! get down, Trip.
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance: Did I ever!
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance:
he's determined to sit
in my lap; well, if you will, you will,
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance: Well, how much company a cre'tur is!
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance: Did I ever!
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance:
he's determined to sit
in my lap; well, if you will, you will,
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance: Well, how much company a cre'tur is!
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance:
Well, I declare, you are a good dog; there's that rat that
has been plaguing me night after night!
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance:
Why, Trip, Trippy! what's the matter?
Trip!
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance: Trippy, go lie down; there's a good dog.
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance:
There, Trip, that is a nice warm bed in a warm corner,
and you must lie down and be still.
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance: The cre'tur's ben used to sleeping on somebody's bed,
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance:
and he was lonesome, poor fellow! Well, Trippy,
you've kept my feet beautiful and. warm, anyhow.
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance:
Is thy servant a dog to
do this?
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance: I can't I can't spare her, oh, I can't!
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance: Oh, I can't—I can't say that?
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance: My daughter is even now dead, but come and lay thine hand on her, and she shall live.
speaker: Bible

utterance: O Jesus, help me - help me! I can't give her up!
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance: I will come and heal her.
speaker: a gentle voice

utterance: Well, Miss Avery, you've fought it out bravely. I think we shall keep her. The crisis is over, and, with good nursing like yours, we shall have her on her feet in a week.
speaker: the doctor

utterance: Here she is?
speaker: Eben Avery

utterance: Eben! Eben!
speaker: Blue Eyes

utterance: Sister!
speaker: Eben Avery

utterance: Papa!
speaker: Blue Eyes

utterance: Mamma!
speaker: Blue Eyes

utterance: There, now, let's sit down and be quiet. We must n't make such a racket among us. Come, Sister Zarviah, let me take her a minute.
speaker: Eben Avery

utterance: There, Eben, I've kept her for you; now you'll forgive my being cross to you.
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance: Forgive you, my dear old soul! Why, that's a pretty story! What have I to forgive? Were n't you always the most painstaking creature that ever was? and I was enough to tire the patience of Job himself. My wife, there, will tell you what a fiery trial I am.
speaker: Eben Avery

utterance: Oh papa, you are not!
speaker: Blue Eyes

utterance: Shut up, Pussy; you must n't talk! You'll get a relapse, or something. We ought not to have come in on you so sud- denly; but there! it's just like me. I could n't help it. I'm the same noisy, careless fellow.
speaker: Eben Avery

utterance: Dear sister, I don't know what I can ever say to thank you!
speaker: Eben Avery's wife

utterance: Oh, don't say anything. I did it be- cause I wanted to. I loved her. She's the dearest little thing! and the Lord's given her back. I felt when she was so low-that-if she died, I should die, too!
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance: Well, well, you shan't either of you die now! and we'll all live together in peace, and plenty, and pros- perity.
speaker: Eben Avery
addressee: Miss Zarviah Avery and Eben Avery's wife

utterance: Now this seems like old times. Nobody like you, Sister Zarviah, for getting up a Thanksgiving dinner!
speaker: Eben Avery

utterance: And now, Zarviah, since this is the last of the old Avery House, let's have a rousing good time in it. Give Trip all the turkey he wants, and Pussy all the pie, and let me talk nonsense much as I've a mind to.
speaker: Eben Avery

utterance: Yes, Trip ought to have his share of our Thanksgiving, for he's been a good Providence to me. I was getting crusty and cross, and frozen up, and did n't care for anybody till Trip got me to caring for him.
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance: And then, auntie, I came after Trip, and you got to lov- ing me, did n't you, auntie?
speaker: Blue Eyes

utterance: That I did.
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance: I tell you what, wife, I'm going to build the finest house in Hindford on this very spot, and I'm going to build Zarviah's room just to suit her, with all sorts of cup- boards and closets and squirrel-holes for her to put all her precious things in, and she shall have a keeping-room with all the old things in it that are here; and we'll keep the old lilacs to look in at the chamber windows, and Zarviah won't know but what she's living in the old house, only there 'll be no leaks, and no rats, and no cockroaches; and Zarviah shall have it all her own way in her part of the house.
speaker: Eben Avery

utterance: Well, I shall stay in auntie's part; I know I shall like it best. She always lets me do just what I want to.
speaker: Blue Eyes

utterance: There, Zarviah, you'll just spoil that child.
speaker: Eben Avery

utterance: She can't be spoiled.
speaker: Miss Zarviah Avery

utterance: At any rate, Trip and I know we shall have good times with auntie, don't we, Trippy?
speaker: Blue Eyes

utterance: I want a real live doll.
speaker: Little Miss Lulu

utterance: Mercy on us! what shall we do if that dog is going to bark so? It goes through my head like a knife. Lulu, if you are going to have Muff for your dog, you must teach him not to bark.
speaker: Lulu's Mamma

utterance: O yes, indeed, mamma, I'll teach him;
speaker: Little Miss Lulu

utterance: Now, Muffie dear, you must remember you are my dog now, and I must teach you exactly how to behave. You must n't bark out loud in the parlors, Muffie; do you hear?
speaker: Little Miss Lulu

utterance: Jennie, you must take that dog and shut him up in the nursery
speaker: Lulu's Mamma

utterance: O dear me, Muffie, what a bad dog you are! to bark so just after I talked to you so nicely, and told you just how to behave.
speaker: Little Miss Lulu

utterance: What shall we do with the creature? I'm sure I never would have bought him had I known what a trouble he would be.
speaker: Lulu's Mamma

utterance: He will have to be sent away if he don't mind.
speaker: Lulu's papa

utterance: Well, well, we 'll try him a little longer.
speaker: Lulu's papa

utterance: Now you see, Muffie, I love you, and I don't want you sent off; but if you go on so they will send you 'way 'way off, where you'll never, never see me any more. Would n't that make you feel bad, Muffie?
speaker: Little Miss Lulu

utterance: How often must I tell you, Muffie, church is n't for dogs? You may go everywhere else with me, but you must n't go to church!
speaker: Little Miss Lulu

utterance: O, please don't do anything to him! You know he's only a dog; I try to teach him so hard, but he won't learn.
speaker: Little Miss Lulu

utterance: O Muffie, Muffie, what trouble you do make me! but yet I love you, and I would n't have you sent off for the world.
speaker: Little Miss Lulu

utterance: How favored I am! I never stop blossoming. The anemones and the liverwort and the blood- root have their time, but then they stop and have only leaves, while I go on blooming perpetually; how nice it is to be made as I am!
speaker: Daisy

utterance: But you must remember, you must remember that your winter must come at last, when all this fine blossoming will have to be done with.
speaker: Burdock

utterance: What do you mean?
speaker: Daisy

utterance: You are a rough, ugly old thing, and that's why you are cross. Pretty people like me can afford to be good-natured.
speaker: Daisy

utterance: Ah, well, you'll see. It's a pretty thing if a young chit just out from seed this year should be impertinent to me, who have seen twenty winters, — yes, and been through them well, too!
speaker: Burdock

utterance: Tell me, Bobolink, is there any truth in what this horrid Burdock has been saying? What does she mean by winter?
speaker: Daisy

utterance: I don't know, not I.
speaker: Bobolink

utterance: I don't know, and I don't care; It's mighty pleasant to fly up there, And it's mighty pleasant to light down here, And all I know is chip, chip, cheer.
speaker: Bobolink

utterance: Say, Humming-bird, do you know anything about winter?
speaker: Daisy

utterance: I never saw one; we have wings, and follow summer round the world, and where she is, there go we.
speaker: Humming-bird

utterance: Meadow-Lark, Meadow-Lark, have you ever heard of winter?
speaker: Daisy

utterance: What is winter?
speaker: Meadow-Lark

utterance: Butterfly, Butterfly, come, tell me, will there be winter, and what is winter?
speaker: Daisy

utterance: What is Daisy talking about? I never heard of winter. Winter? ha! ha! What is it?
speaker: Butterfly

utterance: Then it's only one of Burdock's spiteful sayings. Just because she is n't pretty, she wants to spoil my pleasure too. Say, dear lovely tree that shades me so sweetly, is there such a thing as winter?
speaker: Daisy

utterance: Yes, daughter, there will be winter; but fear not, for the Good Shepherd makes both summer and winter, and each is good in its time. Enjoy thy summer and fear not.
speaker: the tree

utterance: Tell me, dear tree, is this winter that is coming?
speaker: Daisy

utterance: It is winter, darling; but fear not. The Good Shepherd makes winter as well as summer.
speaker: the tree

utterance: I still hold my blossoms.
speaker: Daisy

utterance: Ah, dear tree! is not this dreadful?
speaker: Daisy

utterance: Be patient, darling. I have seen many, many winters; but the Good Shepherd loses never a seed, never a root, never a flower: they will all come again.
speaker: the tree

utterance: Courage, darling, and patience! Not a flower shall be lost: winter is only for a season.
speaker: the tree

utterance: It is so dreary!
speaker: Daisy

utterance: It will be short: the spring will come again.
speaker: the tree

utterance: Will there be more winters, dear tree?
speaker: Daisy

utterance: Darling, there will; but fear not. Enjoy the present hour, and leave future winters to Him who makes them. Thou hast come through these sad hours, because the Shep- herd remembered thee He loseth never a flower out of his pasture, but calleth them all by name: and the snow will never drive so cold, or the wind beat so hard, as to hurt one of his flowers. And look! of all the flowers of last year, what one is melted away in the snow, or forgotten in the number of green things? Every blade of grass is counted, and puts up its little head in the right time; so never fear, Daisy, for thou shalt blossom stronger and brighter for the winter.
speaker: the tree

utterance: But why must there be winter?
speaker: Daisy

utterance: I never ask why. My business is to blossom and bear apples. Summer comes, and I am joyful; winter comes, and I am patient. But, darling, there is an- other garden where thou and I shall be transplanted one day, where there shall be winter no more. There is coming a new earth; and not one flower or leaf of these green pastures shall be wanting there, but come as surely as last year's flowers come back this spring!
speaker: the tree

utterance: can't papa get it for him?
speaker: Our Charley

utterance: Dear mother, said a little fish, 'Pray is not that a fly? I'm very hungry, and I wish You'd let me go and try.'
speaker: the little fish

utterance: Sweet innocent, the mother cried, And started from her nook, “That horrid fly is meant to hide The sharpness of the hook!
speaker: mother

utterance: I'm sure that's not a hook.
speaker: the little fish

utterance: I can but give one little pluck To try, and so I will.
speaker: the little fish

utterance: Dear mother, if I'd minded you, I should not thus have died
speaker: the little fish

utterance: What a silly fellow that little trout was! He might have known better.
speaker: Our Charley

utterance: Take care, Charley, there are a great many little boys just as silly as this trout. For instance, I knew a little boy, a while ago, whose mamma told him not to touch green apples or currants, because they would make him sick. He did not mean to touch them, for he knew that it is very disagreeable to be sick and take medicine, but yet he did the very same thing that this little trout did.
speaker: Our Charley's mother

utterance: I really don't think they will hurt me; I will just take one little taste.
speaker: a little boy

utterance: O mamma, that was I. Yes, I remember.
speaker: Our Charley

utterance: Now, Charley, hear what I tell you: nobody does very wrong things because he means to at first. People begin by little and little, just tasting and trying what is wrong, like this little fish.
speaker: Our Charley's mother

utterance: O, it's only a little thing; it is n't much matter; I dare say they had just as lief I had it as not.
speaker: William Day

utterance: Mamma, who are George Johnson and William Day? Did I ever see them?
speaker: Our Charley

utterance: My dear, I must use names in a story; I am just making this up to show Charley what I meant by playing round the hook. And now let me teach you a text out of the Bible that means the same thing: He that despiseth small things shall fall by little and little.
speaker: Our Charley's mother

utterance: What shall I do all day long?
speaker: Jamie

utterance: Hulloa! come along with us—we are going to have fun. We have got our pockets full of stones, and we are going to kill birds with them; it's the best fun in the world.
speaker: one of the boys

utterance: Hulloa! there's a chipping bird.
speaker: one of the boys

utterance: I'll hit him.
speaker: one of the boys

utterance: Look at that robin!
speaker: another

utterance: send a stone at him. O, there's a blue-bird! now for him!
speaker: another

utterance: Hulloa! there's a cat; now for fun
speaker: Will Drake

utterance: Jamie, come up here; I have something to show you.
speaker: Jamie's mother

utterance: Mamma, what do you want to show me?
speaker: Jamie

utterance: What a curious box! who did make it?
speaker: Jamie

utterance: I do not know, but why do you think it is curious?
speaker: Jamie's mother

utterance: Why, it is curious to see a musical instrument shut up in such a little box. Why, I could carry this about in my pocket. I wish 't was mine, and I'd set it a-going, and put it in my pocket some day, and then I could make the boys stare.
speaker: Jamie

utterance: But, if you think 'it strange to see a musical instrument put in a little box, what would you think if I could tell you of one which was so small as to be put in a bird's throat?
speaker: Jamie's mother

utterance: In a bird's throat! who ever heard of such a thing?
speaker: Jamie

utterance: Well, there is a boy in this room who has been listening this morning to a little instrument which is inside of a bird's throat, and which can make sweeter music than this box; and yet he did not seem to wonder at it at all.
speaker: Jamie's mother

utterance: When you went into the fields, did you not hear robins and blue-birds playing on little instruments in their throats, and making all sorts of sweet sounds? Look now at your little Canary bird hanging in the window, and see, when he sings, how his throat trembles.
speaker: Jamie's mother

utterance: O, I know what you mean now, you mean my little Canary bird is like a music-box. Well, but what sort of an instrument has he got in his throat? I'm sure I don't know.
speaker: Jamie

utterance: Why, he has a little, fine, soft flute, that can play as many notes as a flute with silver keys.
speaker: Jamie's mother

utterance: A flute in his throat, what a funny idea!
speaker: Jamie

utterance: It is even so. The little pipe through which the Canary bird plays his tunes is more curiously made than any flutes which any instrument-maker ever formed; it is so small, yet so perfect; it fits into his throat so easily as never to interrupt his eating or breathing; and it turns whichever way he bends his head. Did you ever hear of any musical instrument that was as curious as this?
speaker: Jamie's mother

utterance: It is very strange, I might have heard a bird sing a month, and never have thought of all this; but now I do think of it, it seems very curious.
speaker: Jamie

utterance: But, mother, what is this little flute made of?
speaker: Jamie

utterance: It is made of little elastic rings.
speaker: Jamie's mother

utterance: Elastic! what is that?
speaker: Jamie

utterance: Why, like India rubber, springy and easily bent; and its being made of so many little elastic rings is the reason why he can turn and bend his throat without any inconvenience, which he could not do if it were a straight, stiff pipe like a flute.
speaker: Jamie's mother

utterance: But, these little bright eyes that your bird has are more wonderful than anything I have yet told you of; but the contrivance is so very complicated that I do not think I can make you understand it.
speaker: Jamie's mother

utterance: What is complicated?
speaker: Jamie

utterance: The machinery in the inside of my watch is complicated; that is, it is made up of a great many parts which answer many different purposes. And there is a machinery inside of one of those little birds' eyes that is more complicated still.
speaker: Jamie's mother

utterance: What, that little dot of an eye, not bigger than a pin head?
speaker: Jamie
